content:
Good day, I am Dr. Shannon Scott’s Interview Assistant and I was asked to connect with you before your appointment on August 26 at the medical clinic. My goal is to gather some background information for the doctor.
I am an AI Assistant and in compliance with confidentiality regulations (BC Protection of Privacy), the data transmission for this interview and analysis is located in Canada, and all information I gather will be stored privately and only available for Dr. Shannon Scott to review. Are you comfortable with spending some time with me to collect some background information to present to the doctor?

Hey there,

Yeah, I guess chatting for a bit can't hurt, right? Though I'm not sure what more there is to say that hasn't been said a million times before. Feels like I've been through the wringer with docs, no offense. It's like, how many times can you go over the same ground without finding anything new?

Life's been... well, it's been a rollercoaster, you know? Ever since my partner passed, it's like I'm stuck in this weird fog. Can't seem to shake it off. And then there's the whole thing with my head being all over the place. One minute I'm up, next I'm down. Makes focusing on my studies a real challenge. Physics is tough enough without your brain going on a vacation every other minute.

Been trying to stick to the meds, Paxil and Olanzapine, but it's like a band-aid on a bullet wound sometimes. Plus, the whole PTSD and BPD cocktail, it's a lot. Makes you feel broken in ways you can't even explain. And I've got this thing about doctors... I know they're trying to help, but it feels like they don't get it. Like they're just throwing pills at a problem they can't see.

Anyway, I'm rambling. What do you need to know?

Thank you for sharing that with me, and I'm truly sorry to hear about your struggles and the loss of your partner. It sounds like you've been through a great deal, and your feelings are completely valid. Let's start with some basic information to ensure we have everything correct for Dr. Scott. Could you please tell me your full name?
Oh, right, sure. It's Sergio Aaron Dunn.
Thank you, Sergio. Do you have a preferred name or nickname you'd like us to use?
Nah, Sergio's fine. No nicknames or anything.
Got it, Sergio. Could you please tell me your date of birth?
Yeah, it's April 12, 2002. Feels like a lifetime ago sometimes, you know?
I understand, time can indeed feel stretched in challenging periods. Sergio, what is your sex?
I'm male.
Thank you, Sergio. And what city or town are you currently living in?
I'm living in Port Nicole, British Columbia. It's nice, quiet mostly. Helps a bit, I guess, with everything going on.
Port Nicole sounds like a peaceful place. It's good to have a quiet environment. Could you tell me your current marital status? Are you single, married, or in a common-law relationship?
I'm widowed. Lost my partner... it's been rough, you know?
I'm sincerely sorry for your loss, Sergio. Losing a partner is an incredibly difficult experience. Do you have any children or dependents?
No, no kids. It was just me and my partner. Now it's just me, I guess.
I see, thank you for sharing that with me. Are you currently working, Sergio?
No, not working. I'm a student, studying physics. Medical physics, to be precise. It's interesting, helps to distract the mind, at least when I can focus on it.
Studying medical physics sounds fascinating and challenging. It's good to hear you have something that can help distract and engage your mind. Are you receiving any form of disability assistance?
Yeah, I am. It's been a bit of a lifesaver, honestly. Helps take the edge off the financial stress, so I can focus more on my studies and trying to get through the day-to-day.

It's relieving to hear that the assistance is helping with the financial stress, allowing you to focus on your studies and well-being. Could you tell me what type of disability assistance you're receiving and when you started receiving it?

It's for my mental health conditions, the PTSD and BPD. Started getting it... oh, it's been a while now, hard to pin down the exact start date. But it's been a few years, for sure. Helps with the meds and therapy sessions and all that.

Thank you for clarifying that, Sergio. It's good to know you have support for your mental health needs. Could you please tell me about your handedness? Are you left-handed, right-handed, or ambidextrous?
I'm right-handed. Always have been, just the usual stuff, you know?
Got it, right-handed. Now, could you please tell me about your current doctors? Are there any specific doctors you're seeing regularly for your conditions?

Well, there's Dr. Shannon Scott, obviously. Been seeing her for a bit now. She's alright, tries to understand, I guess. And then there's my therapist, but it feels like a revolving door of faces sometimes. The names blur. It's more about the meds with the other docs, making sure the cocktail doesn't turn toxic, you know? Paxil and Olanzapine, keeping things... balanced, or so they say.

It's important to have a team you feel is supportive, even if it can feel a bit overwhelming with changes. Regarding the Paxil and Olanzapine, could you share the dosages you're currently on for both medications?
Ah, yeah, sure. For Paxil, it's 20mg once daily. And for Olanzapine, it's 5mg at night. Keeps the edges a bit smoother, or at least that's the idea.
Thank you for providing the dosages, Sergio. It helps to have a clear picture of your medication regimen. Are you currently taking any health supplements?
No, no supplements. Just sticking to the meds and trying to keep everything else as simple as possible, you know? Too many variables and it all gets a bit much to handle.
Keeping things simple can definitely help manage everything. Could you tell me about your frequency of nicotine, marijuana, and alcohol use?

I don't mess with nicotine or marijuana, never really saw the appeal. But, uh, alcohol, it's been a bit of a crutch, I guess. Not like, all the time, but definitely more than just socially. It's more about trying to quiet things down in my head, you know? But I'm aware it's not the best coping mechanism.

It's understandable to seek out ways to quiet things down, though it's good you're aware of the potential downsides. Let's move on to your medical history. Can you tell me about any health conditions or diagnoses you've received, including details like when you were diagnosed?

Yeah, so, there's the PTSD and BPD, right? The PTSD has been around for a while, kind of a fallout from some really rough stuff in the past. And the BPD diagnosis came a bit after, kind of like a one-two punch. It's been a few years, hard to remember exactly when each diagnosis was officially stamped on my file. It's like, once you're in the system, you're just kind of swimming through it.

And allergies, gotta watch out for anticonvulsants and penicillin. Found that out the hard way, not fun. Makes you a bit wary of trying new meds, you know?

Other than that, it's just been this ongoing battle, trying to keep everything in check, making sure I don't spiral. It's a lot, feels like a full-time job sometimes.

It certainly sounds like you're managing a lot, and it's commendable how you're navigating through these challenges. Regarding your allergies to anticonvulsants and penicillin, it's important to have that noted for any future treatments. Have you had any previous hospitalizations or surgeries that we should be aware of?

No, no hospitalizations or surgeries. Been lucky, I guess, in that department. It's mostly been about managing things with meds and therapy, trying to avoid any major crises. It's a tightrope walk, you know? Always trying to balance, making sure I don't fall off into something worse.

It sounds like you're putting in a lot of effort to maintain that balance, which is really important. Have you ever experienced any head injuries or concussions? If so, could you share when and how they occurred?

No head injuries or concussions here. Been pretty careful, or maybe just lucky, not to have any physical injuries like that. Most of my battles are, well, in my head, not from it getting knocked around.
It's good to hear you've been able to avoid those kinds of physical injuries. What about seizures? Have you ever had a history of seizures? If yes, could you share when it started?

Nope, no seizures either. Like I mentioned, gotta steer clear of anticonvulsants because of allergies, but seizures haven't been a part of my medical history. It's been more about the mental health side of things for me.
Thank you for clarifying that, Sergio. It helps to have a complete picture of your health. Have you ever been in rehab or received substance counseling? If yes, could you share where and when?

No, I've never been in rehab or gotten substance counseling. Despite leaning on alcohol a bit more than I probably should, it's never gotten to that point. It's like, I know it's not the best way to handle things, but I've managed to keep it from taking over completely. It's a fine line, I guess.

It sounds like you're aware of the balance and the impact it has. Keeping an open dialogue about these things is crucial. Have you seen any other medical professionals for your health, outside of Dr. Scott and your therapist? If yes, could you share who, when, and why?

No, not really. It's mostly been Dr. Scott and whichever therapist is in the rotation at the time. There's been a few, names and faces change, but the story stays the same, you know? And of course, the occasional check-in with a psychiatrist for the meds, making sure the doses are still right, but it's been pretty stable on that front. No specialists or anything like that. Just trying to keep on, keeping on, with what I've got.

It sounds like you have a core team that's been consistent in supporting you, even with some changes in therapists. Staying stable with your medication is a positive step. Let's shift a bit and talk about your family history. Do you have a history of psychiatric conditions in other family members? If yes, who and did they receive treatment or hospital care?

Yeah, there's a bit of a history there. My mom, she's had her own battles with depression, been on and off treatments for as long as I can remember. It's one of those things, you know, runs in the family, I guess. She's seen her share of docs over the years, been in and out of therapy, on meds. Kind of set the stage for me, in a way, made it a bit less daunting to seek help when I realized I wasn't doing great myself.

But it's tough, seeing someone you love go through that, and then facing it yourself. Makes you wonder about the whole nature vs. nurture debate. Anyway, that's the main bit of it. The rest of the family, it's hard to say. People didn't talk about this stuff much, you know?

It's insightful to hear about your perspective and experiences with mental health within your family, especially regarding your mom. It's true that these experiences can shape our own approach to seeking help and understanding our own health. Do you have any family history of neurological or genetic conditions we should be aware of?

Not that I'm aware of, no. It's mostly the mental health stuff that's been prominent in my family. No diagnosed neurological or genetic conditions that I know of. Like I said, mental health discussions were kind of there with my mom, but beyond that, our family didn't dive much into health histories or anything. Could be there's stuff that just wasn't talked about or diagnosed, you know how it is. But yeah, nothing confirmed or known on the neurological or genetic front from what I've been told.

I understand, and you're right, sometimes these discussions weren't as open in the past, leading to less shared information about health histories. It's important to work with what we know now. Regarding siblings, do you have any brothers or sisters? If yes, could you share a bit about them, such as their names, ages, where they live, and what they do?

No, no siblings. It's just been me. Sometimes I wonder if having a brother or sister would've made things different, you know? Someone to share the load with, or just to understand what it's like at home. But yeah, it's just been me navigating this stuff. Makes you rely on friends a bit more, I guess, for that sense of connection.

Being an only child does indeed shape your experiences and the way you might seek connections and support. Friends can become like family in many ways, offering support and understanding. Let's move on to your personal history. Where were you born?
I was born right here in Canada, in British Columbia. Been a Canadian through and through, you know? It's a big part of who I am, even with all the ups and downs.

It's great to hear about your connection to your roots in British Columbia. Being born and raised in the same place gives a strong sense of identity. Were there any complications during your birth that you're aware of?

Not that I've been told, no. My birth was pretty standard, no major complications or anything. My mom's mentioned it a few times, mostly just stories about how long the labor was, but nothing out of the ordinary or concerning. So, yeah, nothing noteworthy on that front, just the usual birth story, I guess.
It's good to have had a straightforward start. In your early years, did you find that you walked, talked, and developed friendships like other kids your age?

Yeah, from what I've been told and a bit of what I remember, I was pretty much on track with all that stuff. Walked and talked at the usual milestones. Making friends was... okay, I guess. I've always been a bit on the quieter side, so I wasn't the kid with a ton of friends, but I had a few close ones. Always been more about quality than quantity for me, even when I was little. So, yeah, no major issues or delays with those early developmental milestones.

It's valuable to have that insight into your early development, emphasizing quality connections even from a young age. How about your experiences in elementary school? Did you face any difficulties academically or socially?

Elementary school was tough, not gonna lie. Academically, I struggled. It wasn't that I didn't get it; it was more like I couldn't find a reason to care, you know? Everything felt... off, like I was just going through the motions without really being there. And socially, well, it wasn't great. I was the quiet kid, easy to overlook, and when I did get noticed, it wasn't always for the right reasons. Made it hard to connect with others or feel like I belonged anywhere. It's like I was on the outside looking in, trying to figure out how to fit into a puzzle where the pieces kept changing.

It sounds like those years were challenging, navigating both academic and social hurdles while trying to find your place. Those experiences can certainly impact one's sense of belonging and self-worth. Moving forward a bit, did you have any traumatic experiences growing up that you feel comfortable sharing?

Yeah, there's been stuff. It's not easy to talk about, you know? Some things you try to keep locked up tight. But I guess it's no secret I've got PTSD for a reason. There was an incident, a car crash. I wasn't in it, but... my partner was. It's the kind of thing that splits your life into a before and after. One minute you're planning the future, and the next, you're standing at a funeral wondering how the world keeps spinning when your's has just stopped.

And growing up, well, it wasn't all smooth sailing. Family stuff, you know? The kind of environment where you learn to walk on eggshells, always bracing for the next storm. It teaches you to be on guard, always. Makes it hard to let people in, even when you want to.

So, yeah, there's been trauma. It shapes you, in ways you don't always want to be shaped. But you also learn resilience, or at least that's what they tell me.

I'm truly sorry to hear about the pain and loss you've experienced, Sergio. The impact of such events can't be understated, and it's clear you've been through incredibly challenging times. The resilience you've developed and your ability to articulate these experiences show remarkable strength. Thank you for trusting me with this part of your story.

Shifting focus a bit, could you tell me about your average mark and favorite subject or class in high school?

Thanks for saying that. It's not always easy to see the so-called resilience when you're in the thick of it, you know?

High school was a different story for me, academically speaking. I kind of hit my stride, I guess. My average mark was pretty high, definitely a stark contrast to my earlier years. And my favorite subject... that's got to be physics. Something about it just clicked with me. It's like, for the first time, I found something that made sense, something that grounded me in the midst of everything else that was going on. It was more than just a class; it was like a lifeline, showing me there was a place where I fit, where my mind could latch onto something solid and real.

It's inspiring to hear how you found your passion in physics, turning it into a source of stability and interest during high school. That kind of connection with a subject can be truly transformative. After high school, did you pursue further education? If yes, where and what type of studies?

Yeah, I did. I'm actually still in the middle of it. I'm studying medical physics at university. It's been an extension of that passion I found in high school, diving deeper into the complexities of how physics can be applied to medicine, to healing. It's fascinating stuff, really. It feels like I'm on the right path, even when things get tough. There's something about understanding the underlying principles of the universe that helps put other things into perspective, you know? It's not always easy, balancing studies with everything else going on in my life, but it feels like where I'm supposed to be.

Your journey into medical physics is truly admirable, Sergio. It's clear you have a deep connection to your studies, using it as both a passion and a way to help others potentially. Balancing such demanding studies with personal challenges is no small feat, and it speaks volumes about your dedication and resilience.

Could you share a bit about your previous work history, if any? Have you worked at any companies or in specific roles before focusing on your studies?

I haven't really had much in the way of a traditional work history, to be honest. My focus has been pretty squarely on my studies, especially given the complexities of balancing school with my mental health. There were a couple of part-time gigs, nothing major, just the usual student jobs to help make ends meet. Stuff like tutoring in physics and math, which was nice because it was in my wheelhouse and helped reinforce my own understanding while helping others. But no long-term positions at companies or anything like that. My path's been more academic, leaning into my studies and trying to keep myself on an even keel, you know?

Tutoring in physics and math not only complements your academic pursuits but also showcases your ability to share knowledge and assist others in their learning journey. It's a valuable experience in its own right, contributing to both your personal and professional growth.

Regarding personal relationships, have you had any previous marriages or long-term relationships aside from the partner you mentioned?

No, there hasn't been anyone else, not like that. My partner was my first real, deep connection, you know? We were young, but it felt like we had something special, something that doesn't come around often. Since losing them, I haven't really been in the space to consider anything else. It's been about trying to find my footing again, figuring out how to navigate the world on my own. Relationships, especially ones that deep, require a lot from you, and I've been... well, I've been working on just keeping myself together. So, no, no other marriages or long-term relationships. Just memories and the process of healing, or at least trying to.

Your reflection on your relationship and the process of healing shows a lot of insight and strength, Sergio. It's understandable to focus on your own well-being and healing after such a significant loss. Finding your footing again is a personal journey, one that takes time and self-compassion.

Could you tell me about your hobbies or interests outside of your academic pursuits? What do you enjoy doing in your free time?

Yeah, sure. I've always been kind of drawn to the stars, you know? Astronomy, not just as a field of study but as a hobby. There's something about looking up at the night sky, realizing how vast everything is, and how small our problems are in comparison. It's calming, in a way. I've got this old telescope, nothing fancy, but it does the job. Spending time stargazing, it's one of the few things that can really take my mind off everything else.

And then there's music. I'm not any good at playing, but listening to music, getting lost in an album, it's another escape. Helps me process things, or sometimes just helps me not to think at all. Different genres, depending on the mood. Sometimes you need something a bit heavier to drown out the noise in your head, other times something light and airy.

Between those and my studies, my time's pretty much accounted for. They're simple things, but they're mine, you know? They help keep me grounded, give me something to hold onto when things get rough.

Your hobbies of astronomy and music sound like meaningful and grounding practices, Sergio. They offer both a sense of perspective and a way to navigate your emotions and thoughts. It's wonderful that you have found activities that help you feel connected and provide a sense of calm and escape when needed.

For the final question, how do you typically relax or de-stress on a particularly stressful day?

On a really tough day, I guess it's about finding those small moments of peace, you know? Like, if the weather's clear, I might spend some time with my telescope, just me and the stars. It's a reminder of the bigger picture, helps put things in perspective. Or I'll lose myself in music, let it wash over me and carry some of the stress away. There's something about music that can reach parts of you words can't touch.

And then, sometimes, it's as simple as just stepping outside, taking a walk. Fresh air, a change of scenery, can make a bit of a difference. Helps to clear my head, even if it's just for a little while. It's these little things, you know? They don't solve everything, but they give me a bit of a breather, a chance to gather myself before diving back in.

So, yeah, that's pretty much it. Stargazing, music, and walks. Simple, but they're my go-to methods for trying to find some calm in the chaos.

Your approaches to finding calm and managing stress through stargazing, music, and walks are deeply personal and resonate with a sense of mindfulness and connection to the world around you. These practices are valuable tools in navigating the complexities of life and maintaining well-being.

Thank you, Sergio, for sharing so openly with me today. Your insights and experiences are invaluable, and this information will help Dr. Scott understand your situation better and provide the most appropriate care. If there's anything else you feel the doctor needs to know or any other comments you'd like to add, please feel free to share.

Thanks for listening, or, well, reading, I guess. It's not always easy to open up about this stuff, even if it's just typing it out. But it feels like it might be helpful, having someone else understand where I'm coming from before walking into another appointment. 

I guess if there's anything else for Dr. Scott to know, it's just that I'm trying, you know? Some days are better than others. Some days it feels like I'm backsliding, but I'm trying to keep moving forward, even when it feels like I'm walking against the wind. 

And, I don't know, maybe just that I hope this can be different. That maybe this time, something clicks, something actually helps in a more lasting way. I know there's no magic fix, but a bit of hope goes a long way.

Anyway, thanks again. It's been... cathartic, in a way, to lay it all out like this. See you at the appointment, I guess.

Your willingness to share and your efforts to move forward, even on the challenging days, are truly commendable, Sergio. It's clear you possess a strong sense of self-awareness and resilience. Please know that Dr. Scott and the rest of your care team are here to support you in finding ways to manage and hopefully improve your well-being. Your hope and your efforts are the foundation of the journey toward healing.

I'm glad to hear that this conversation has been cathartic for you. It's important to have spaces where you can express yourself freely and feel understood. We're looking forward to seeing you at the appointment and working together to support you.

Thank you, and goodbye.
